['Top hat - A tall, flat-crowned hat often worn with tuxedos or evening dresses at weddings and galas.', "Homburg - A semi-formal felt hat typically associated with men's fashion in the early to mid-20th century.", 'Fedora - A soft, wide brimmed hat made of rabbit or beaver fur originally popularized by gangsters in the 1920s.', 'Trilby - A low-crowned hat with a narrow brim and flat crown; named after George Westlake\'s character in the play "Lady Windermere\'s Fan."', 'Beret - A soft, round, flat-crowned hat typically made of wool, popularized by artists and military personnel alike.', 'Panama hat - Originally from Ecuador, these wide brimmed hats are made of natural fibers such as cocona palm leaves.', "Bowler (derby) - A sturdy round flat-crowned hat with a short brim; named after Samuel Beechey's wife Sarah Bowler in 1849.", 'Cloche hat - A fitted, bell-shaped hat that was popular during the Roaring Twenties and can be worn over formal gowns or evening dresses.', "Sunhat (Gardenia) - A women's wide brimmed, floppy hat with a floral design often associated with garden parties or summer events.", 'Toupée - While not specifically for formal occasions, it is still an accessory worn by men to cover baldness and can be styled up during special events.', 'Zoot suit jacket (hat) - A tailored, oversized jacket with a long coat-like silhouette popular in the 1940s, often accompanied by a fedora or porkpie hat.', 'Topcoat - A type of formal overcoat traditionally worn with evening gowns and tuxedos, usually paired with top hats.', 'Bowtie (hat) - A small, semi-circular piece of fabric tied around the neck in a bow; though not typically considered formal wear itself, it can be worn as part of a formal outfit for men.', 'Pillbox hat - A small, round brimmed hat made from stiff felt or other materials; popularized by First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy during her time in the White House.', 'Deerstalker cap (Hat) - A type of tweed hunting cap with a checkered pattern and a fold-over front, named after its association with Scottish deer stalking tradition', 'Tuxedo hat (top hat) - A black or white top hat worn as part of a tuxedo ensemble at more elegant events like balls and galas.', 'Morning coat - A knee-length, formal tailcoat popular during the 19th century; paired with a top hat for morning events such as weddings.', "Eton crop (top hat) - Named after England's prestigious Eton College where it was traditionally worn by students; typically black and formal, often accompanied by an evening dress or tuxedo.", 'Balmoral bonnet (hat) - A flat-topped, round, knitted cap made from wool with ear flaps popularized by Queen Victoria in the 19th century', "Cloche hat (top hat) - A small, bell-shaped brimmed hat that resembles a tilted bowl; though typically associated with women and daytime wear in the 1920s, it's possible for formal events if styled appropriately."]

['Banter - casual and playful conversation or exchange of remarks.', 'Small talk - light, informal chatting about everyday topics without delving into deep discussions.', 'Gossip - friendly but often idle talk concerning the personal affairs of others.', 'Ribbing - teasing in a good-natured manner; joking playfully with someone.', 'Chatterbox - an individual who talks continuously, especially about trivial matters.', 'Spouting - to speak at length or continually without pause.', 'Lilt - the way of speaking characterized by a pleasant rhythm and tone.', 'Gleeful chatting - exchanging cheerful conversation with enthusiasm and joy.', 'Water-cooler conversations - informal discussions that typically take place near office water coolers or break areas.', 'Lighthearted bantering - casual, funny, playful conversation between friends or acquaintances.', 'Jovial jabbering - friendly and humorous exchanges filled with good-natured humor.', 'Fond reminiscing - sharing personal stories and memories in a leisurely manner.', 'Idle prattle - casual, inconsequential conversation without any meaningful content.', 'Soothing chatter - gentle or calm talking that provides comfort or relaxation to those involved.', 'Witty repartee - sharp and clever exchange of verbal remarks in a playful manner.', 'Easy-going gab - informal, lighthearted conversation without any particular topic or purpose.', 'Friendly babble - friendly conversation characterized by unrestricted flow of words.', 'Breezy chatting - relaxed and effortless conversations with a natural rhythm.', 'Casual gabbing - informal, non-serious talk between friends or acquaintances.', 'Whispery banter - light, low volume conversation filled with teasing remarks and jokes.']

['Grumpy - Often used to describe someone who is irritable and bad-tempered, often due to tiredness or discomfort rather than malice.', 'Irritable - Easily annoyed or provoked, possibly stemming from physical or emotional issues.', 'Sulky - Bad-tempered in a morose or resentful way; moodiness that may result from feeling unwell or disappointed.', 'Sullen - Gloomy and sulky; often resulting from discomfort or illness rather than intentional negativity.', 'Choleric - Quick to anger, possibly a symptom of an underlying health issue.', 'Cranky - Bad-tempered in a whiny manner; this can be temporary due to physical discomfort.', 'Icy - Personality characterized by coldness and unapproachability, which may indicate mood swings or illness.', 'Sourpuss - A person who is perpetually grumpy or unhappy, possibly resulting from being in poor health.', 'Grouchy - Always complaining or annoyed; this behavior might be a manifestation of chronic pain or fatigue.', 'Cantankerous - Irritable and difficult to deal with; sometimes associated with old age or physical limitations.', "Disgruntled - Dissatisfied, often in response to health issues affecting one's mood or energy levels.", 'Peevish - Bad-tempered and irritable, which could be due to an underlying illness rather than a personality trait.', 'Touchy - Sensitive and easily upset; this can be related to physical discomfort or emotional sensitivity from being unwell.', 'Cheery - Often used ironically when describing someone who appears generally cheerful, but is actually irritable due to health concerns.', 'Thorny - A metaphor for difficult temperament; this could be a reflection of physical discomfort causing bad moods.', "Grievous - Severe or serious in nature; sometimes used when describing the impact of an illness on someone's demeanor.", 'Cantankerous - Often associated with old age but can also reflect a person’s state due to sickness, making them grumpy and unsociable.', 'Fretful - Worried or anxious; these emotions could stem from feeling physically ill or in pain.', "Grumous - A playful term combining 'grumpy' with a negative suffix, highlighting an irritable state possibly caused by sickness.", 'Ill-tempered - Having a bad temper and often attributed to discomfort or health issues affecting mood stability.']

CLUE: Feeling one has seen something before
OUTPUT: ['Déjà vu - A feeling of having experienced a current situation previously.', 'Prescience - The ability to foresee or predict future events, often associated with sensing familiarity in what seems new.', 'Anamnesis - In Greek mythology and philosophy, the concept of recalling forgotten memories; can relate to feeling like one has seen something before.', 'Recollection - The act of remembering or recollecting past events, which may give a sense of familiarity.', 'Intuition - A gut feeling that often provides insights without clear reasoning, sometimes accompanied by the sensation of prior experience.', 'Premonition - A strong feeling about a future event; can have an element of recognizing something similar to past experiences.', 'Familiarity - The state or quality of being familiar with something, which could be due to previous exposure.', 'Retrospection - Reflecting on the past events and memories that might trigger feelings of déjà vu.', 'Recurrence - When an event or situation repeats itself; can evoke a sense of having witnessed it before.', 'Repetition - The action of doing something again, which may lead to recognizing patterns similar to those previously encountered.', "Predictability - Feeling that events are following a predictable pattern, often making one think they've seen such scenarios before.", 'Convergence - When different experiences or ideas come together; can evoke sensations of déjà vu due to similarities.', 'Synesthesia (specifically involving memory) - A neurological condition where stimulation of one sense leads to automatic, involuntary experiences in a second sense, which could create the illusion of prior knowledge.', 'Semantic satiation - The phenomenon when repetition causes a word or phrase to lose meaning, potentially leading to a feeling that something feels familiar due to overuse.', 'Synchronicity - A concept where seemingly unrelated events occur simultaneously in a way that appears meaningfully connected; can give the impression of seeing things beforehand.', 'Cognitive dissonance - The psychological discomfort from holding conflicting thoughts or beliefs, which may result in attempting to reconcile familiarity with new information.', 'Eidetic memory (especially when related to childhood) - An ability to vividly recall images and experiences; can lead to feelings of déjà vu if the memories are particularly clear.', "Flashbulb memory - A highly detailed, exceptionally vivid 'snapshot' of a moment in time linked with strong emotions, which might make one feel like they have experienced similar situations before.", 'Mnemonic devices (e.g., acronyms) - Techniques used to aid memory; their repetitive use can sometimes trigger feelings that the information or concept has been encountered previously.', 'Simulation theory - The idea that our minds simulate experiences, which could lead to a sense of recognizing something through familiarity despite it being new.']

CLUE: Go faster or do better than
OUTPUT: ['Accelerate - To increase speed rapidly, allowing something to go faster.', 'Improve - Enhancing quality or performance, resulting in doing better.', "Outpace - Surpassing someone's speed; going faster than another entity.", 'Advance - Move forward quickly and efficiently, progressing further ahead.', 'Excel - Perform exceptionally well, surpassing average standards.', 'Boost - Increase the effectiveness or efficiency of something to do better.', 'Speedy - Quick in motion or action; faster than usual.', 'Enhance - Improve the quality or value by adding more features or abilities.', 'Surge - A sudden and forceful increase, particularly in speed or performance.', 'Swiftly - Moving quickly with ease and efficiency, resulting in doing better promptly.', 'Eclipse - Overshadow something; surpass it, often used metaphorically to mean outperforming.', 'Streamline - Improve the design or efficiency of a system for better performance.', 'Turbocharge - Increase power and speed significantly, usually related to engines.', 'Amplify - Increase in strength or scope; improve upon the original capacity.', 'Leapfrog - Jump over others, surpassing them by significant margins.', 'Skyrocket - To increase very rapidly and unexpectedly, often referring to speed or value.', 'Overhaul - Make major improvements to a system or process; do better than before.', 'Trounce - Defeat decisively in competition, outperforming others significantly.', 'Breakneck: Extremely fast or intense pace that may surpass usual expectations.', 'Quantum Leap: A significant and sudden improvement, often used metaphorically to denote drastic progress.']

['Rectangle - A four-sided shape with opposite sides equal and all angles at 90 degrees.', 'Rhombus - A parallelogram where all sides are of equal length but angles may vary.', 'Trapezium (UK) / Trapezoid (US) - A quadrilateral with only one pair of parallel sides.', 'Pentagon - A five-sided polygon.', 'Hexagon - A six-sided polygon with all equal interior angles and sides, typically a regular hexagon has 120 degrees at each vertex.', 'Octagon - An eight-sided figure, often seen in stop signs (regular octagon).', 'Kite (Shape) - Two pairs of adjacent sides are equal, but unlike other quadrilaterals with two sets of equal opposite sides.', 'Parallelogram - A four-sided shape where opposite sides and angles are equal, including rectangles and rhombuses as special cases.', 'Scalene Triangle (non-oblong) - A triangle with all three sides and angles differing from each other.', 'Isosceles Triangle - A triangle with at least two sides of equal length.', 'Equilateral Triangle - An equiangular triangle where all three sides are the same length.', 'Square - A special type of rectangle and rhombus, with all four sides equal and all angles 90 degrees.', 'Diamond (Playing Card) - Typically a square-shaped playing card symbol but not an actual geometric shape.', 'Octagon - In general, this term can refer to any eight-sided figure or structure.', 'Rhombic Prism - A three-dimensional figure with rhombus faces and two parallel, congruent bases.', 'Pentagonal Prism - A polyhedron with pentagonal base(s) and rectangular sides.', 'Hexagonal Prism - A prism with a hexagon as its base.', 'Octagonal Prism - A three-dimensional figure with octagonal bases.', 'Square Pyramid (Pyramid) - An ancient Egyptian architectural form, composed of a square base and triangular sides that converge to a point.', 'Triangular Prism - A polyhedron with two congruent triangles as the top and bottom bases connected by rectangular faces.']
